moves.1. e4 e5 2. f3 d5: I learned my lesson from last time, instead of unleashing my queen to check the king, I moved up her pawn to open her up from another side, and also her bishop. And I also pressure my opponent's pawn.
moves.3... dxe4: ...so I capture his king's pawn in the hope that he'd do the same...
moves.4. dxe5: ...which he does, to open up the d-file...
moves.5. Kxd1: ...forcing him to take mine, so he can't castle.
moves.6... Bg4: Now I bring up the bishop to pin the knight down...
moves.7. Be2: ...so he unleashes his bishop to unpin the knight...
moves.8. h3 O-O-O+: ...so I can castle queenside and place him in check.
moves.10... Nxe5: ...and I also remove the exposed pawn...
moves.12... Nf6: Now I bring up my knight...
moves.13... Bb4: ...I do likewise to my bishop to guarantee a win of at least one of the knight and the bishop.
moves.15. Kd1 Bb2: ...and now I fork the rook and knight.
moves.17. b4 Rxd2+: Now I bring my rook onto the attack...
moves.19. Rb3 Rxf3: ...which I remove, also covering my bishop.
moves.20. Rd1: He moves his other rook out...
moves.21. Rd3: Doubling up on the bishop is fatal...
moves.21... Rf1+: ...as I push my furthest rook to the top rank...
moves.22... Rdxd1#: ...but that shield is easily shattered by my other rook.
